ExoticHiggs.ClusterConfiguration module¶

class ExoticHiggs.ClusterConfiguration.ClusterConfiguration(username, email, group_list, pbs_script_template)¶

Bases: object

A template for creating a cluster configuration.

username¶

str

Your username. For University of Arizona users, this is your NetID.

email¶

str

Your email, used to send notifications when a cluster job begins and ends.

group_list¶

str

The group you belong to. For UA users, this should be the name of your PI in lowercase.

ExoticHiggs.ClusterConfiguration.myClusterConfig = <ExoticHiggs.ClusterConfiguration.ClusterConfiguration object>¶

This is the actual configuration for the cluster, that you must modify before using the package to generate events on the cluster.

ExoticHiggs.Process module¶

class ExoticHiggs.Process.Process(name, model, decay_channel, mg5_generation_syntax, energy, index)¶

Bases: object

A template for a particle collision process.

copy_cards()¶

Copy the run, pythia, and delphes cards to the process directory. The default run card is for 14 TeV. If the energy given is ‘100_TeV’ instead, then the FCC delphes card will be copied.

create_directory()¶

Create a MadGraph5 directory for the process.

generate_events(nruns=1, nevents=10000)¶

Generate events on your local computer.

Parameters:
  • nruns (int) – Number of runs to perform.
  • nevents (int) – Number of events to generate per run.

ExoticHiggs.SignificanceCalculator module¶

class ExoticHiggs.SignificanceCalculator.SignificanceCalculator(s, b_tau_tuples)¶

Class to calculate significance for a simple counting experiment.

Example

If, after cuts, we have the following events left over (for a given luminosity) :

  • Signal : 10 events
  • Background 1 : 20 events ; tau_1 = 0.5
  • Background 2 : 13 events ; tau_2 = 1.5
  • Background 3 : 15 events ; tau_3 = 8

Associated with each background is a factor ‘tau’, which parameterizes the uncertainty from the number of Monte Carlo events generated. For example, if we have the following:

  • \(n_{M}C\) = Number of Monte Carlo events generated for a background.
  • \(\sigma_b\) = Cross-section for the background (output by the generator).
  • \(\mathcal{L}\) = Luminosity for which we would like to calculate the significance.

the factor tau for this background would be:

\[\tau = n_{MC}/(\sigma_b * \mathcal{L})\]

Basically, the more Monte Carlo events you generate, that is, the greater the tau factor is, the more confident you can be that the number of background events that you get after cuts will match what is seen at a detector.

Here is a minimal working program that implements the above:

from SignificanceCalculator import SignificanceCalculator

s = 10
b_tau_tuples = [(20, 0.5), (13, 1.5), (15, 8)]
calc = SignificanceCalculator(s, b_tau_tuples)
calc.print_report()

This should return the following:

$ The expected discovery significance is 0.612969
$ The expected exclusion limit is 1.08637
$ S/sqrt(B) = 1.56
calculate_discovery_significance()¶

Calculates the expected discovery significance.

calculate_exclusion_limit()¶

Calculates the expected exclusion limit

print_report()¶

Prints a report with the expected discovery significance and exclusion limit.

run_SigCalc()¶

Run SigCalc with the inputFile

write_SigCalc_inputFile(n_obs)¶

Write an input file for SigCalc to process.

Parameters:n_obs (int) – Number of events observed in the signal region.

ExoticHiggs.helpers module¶

ExoticHiggs.helpers.cd(*args, **kwds)¶

A context manager to handle temporary directory changes.

Here is an example of how one might use the function:

with cd('relative/path/to/directory'):
    print(os.getcwd()) # Prints the working directory
    subprocess.call('./run_external_program') # Runs some non-python program
Parameters:destination_directory (string) – The directory to temporarily change the working directory to.
ExoticHiggs.helpers.convert_SAF_to_XML(filename)¶

ExoticHiggs.helpers.modify_file(filepath, line_modification_function)¶

Modify a file in place.

Parameters:
  • filepath (str) – Path to the file to be modified.
  • line_modification_function (func) – The line modification function. Takes one parameter, the line, and returns either the original line or a modified version of it.
